editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Price One Shilling and Six Pence.
ACHILLES. AN OPERA. As it is Perform'd at the Theatre-Royal in Covent-Garden.
div.q: Naturam expellas furcâ licet, uſque recurret.
div.p: Written by the late Mr. GAY.
With the MUSICK prefix'd to each SONG.
LONDON: Printed for J. WATTS at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court, near Lincoln's-Inn-Fields. MDCCXXXIII.
Price One Shilling and Six Pence.

lg.l: I Wonder not our Author doubts Succeſs,
One in his Circumſtance can do no leſs.
The Dancer on the Rope that tries at all,
In each unpractis'd Caper riſques a Fall:
I own I dread his tickliſh Situation,
Critics deteſt Poetic Innovation.
Had Ic'rus been content with ſolid Ground,
The giddy vent'rous Youth had ne'er been drown'd.
The Pegaſus of old had Fire and Force,
But your true Modern is a Carrier's Horſe,
Drawn by the foremoſt Bell, afraid to ſtray,
Bard following Bard jogs on the beaten Way.
Why is this Man ſo obſtinate an Elf?
Wall he, alone, not imitate himſelf?
His Scene now ſhews the Heroes of old Greece;
But how? 'tis monſtrous! In a Comic Piece.
To Buskins, Plumes and Helmets what Pretence,
If mighty Chiefs muſt ſpeak but common Senſe?
Shall no bold Diction, no Poetic Rage,
Fome at our Mouths and thunder on the Stage?
No 'tis Achilles, as he came from Chiron,
Juſt taught to ſing as well as wield cold Iron;
And whatſoever Criticks may ſuppoſe,
Our Author holds, that what He ſpoke was Proſe.

sp.speaker: THETIS.
sp.p: BEFORE I leave you, Child, I muſt inſiſt upon your Promiſe, that you will never diſcover yourſelf without my Leave. Don't look upon it as capricious Fondneſs, nor think (becauſe 'tis a Mother's Advice) that in Duty to yourſelf you are oblig'd not to follow it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But my Character! my Honour!— Wou'd you have your Son live with Infamy?—On the firſt Step of a young Fellow depends his Character for Life.—I beg you, Goddeſs, to diſpenſe with your Commands.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Have you then no Regard to my Preſentiment? I can't bear the Thoughts of your going, for I know that odious Siege of Troy wou'd be the Death of thee.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Becauſe you have the natural Fears of a Mother, wou'd you have me inſenſible that I have the Heart of a Man? The World, Madam, muſt look upon my abſconding in this Manner, and at this particular Juncture, as infamous Cowardiſe.

div.head: AIR I. A Clown in Flanders once there was.
div.l: What's Life? No Curſe is more ſevere,
Than bearing Life with Shame.
Is this your Fondneſs? this your Care?
O give me Death with Fame.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Keep your Temper, Achilles:—'Tis both impious and undutiful to call my Preſcience in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Pardon me, Goddeſs, for had you, like other Mothers, been a meer Woman only, I ſhou'd have taken the Liberty of other Sons, and ſhou'd (as 'tis my Duty) have heard your Advice, and follow'd my own.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I poſitively ſhall not be eaſy, Child, unleſs you give me your Word and Honour.—You know my Commands.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: My Word, Madam, I can give you; but my Honour is already ſacrific'd to my Duty. That I gave you when I ſubmitted to put on this Womans Habit.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Believe me, Achilles, I have a tender Regard for your Honour, as well as Life.—By preventing your running head-long to your Deſtiny, I preſerve you for future Glory. Therefore, Child, I once more inſiſt upon your ſolemn Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Was I a Woman (as I appear to be) I cou'd without Difficulty give you a Promiſe to have the Pleaſure of breaking it; but when I promiſe, my Life is pledg'd for the Performance. —Your Commands, Madam, are ſacred.—Yet I intreat you, Goddeſs, to conſider the ignominious Part you make me act.—In obeying you, I prove my ſelf unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: My Will, Achilles, is not to be controverted. Your Life depends upon your Duty; and poſitively, Child, you ſhall not go to this Siege.

div.head: AIR II. Gudgeon's Song.
div.l: Why thus am I held at Defiance?
A Mother, a Goddeſs obey!
Will Men never practiſe Compliance,
Till Marriage hath taught 'em the Way?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But why muſt I lead the Life of a Woman? Why was I ſtolen away from my Preceptor? Was I not as ſafe under the Care of Chiron?—I know the Love he had for me; I feel his Concern; and I dare ſwear that good Creature is now ſo diſtreſs'd for the Loſs of me, that he will quite founder himſelf with galloping from Place to Place to look after me.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I'll hear no more. Obey, and ſeek to know no further. —Can you imagine that I wou'd have taken all this Trouble to have lodg'd you under the Protection of Lycomedes; if I had not ſeen the abſolute Neceſſity of it?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Were I allow'd to follow my Inclinations, what wou'd you have to fear?—I ſhou'd do my Duty, and die with Honour. —Was I to live an Age, I cou'd do no more.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: You are ſo very obſtinate, that really, Child, there's no enduring you.—Your Impatience ſeems to forget that I am a Goddeſs: Have I not degraded my ſelf into the Character of a diſtreſs'd Grecian Princeſs? 'Tis owing to my Artifice and Inſinuation that we have the Protection of the King of Scyros. Have I not won Lycomedes his Friendſhip and Hoſpitality to that degree as to place you, without the leaſt Suſpicion, among his Daughters?—And for what, dear Achilles? —Your Safety and future Fame requir'd it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, Madam, to bear it much longer.— My Words, my Actions, my aukward Behaviour, muſt one Day inevitably diſcover me.—I had been ſafer under the Tuition of Chiron.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p:
Hath not the Prophet Calchas perſuaded the Confederates that the Succeſs of their Expedition againſt Troy depends
upon your being among 'em? Have they not Emiſſaries and Spies almoſt every where in ſearch of you? 'Tis here only, and in this Diſguiſe, that I can believe you out of the Reach of Suſpicion.—You have ſo much Youth, and ſuch a Bloom, that there is no Man alive but muſt take you for a Woman. What I am moſt afraid of is, that when you are among the Ladies you ſhou'd be ſo little Maſter of your Paſſions as to find your ſelf a Man.

div.head: AIR III. Did you ever hear of a galant Sailor.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: The Woman always in Temptation,
Muſt do what Nature bids her do;
Our Hearts feel equal Palpitation,
For we've unguarded Minutes too.
By Nature greedy,
When lank and needy,
Within your Fold the Wolf confine;
Then bid the Glutton
Not think of Mutton;
Can you perſuade him not to dine?

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Now, dear Child, let me beg you to be diſcreet.—I have ſome Sea-Affairs that require my Attendance, which (much againſt my Will) oblige me for a time to leave you to your own Conduct.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The Princeſſes, Lady Pyrrha, have been ſitting at their Embroidery above a Quarter of an Hour, and are perfectly miſerable for want of you.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Pyrrha is ſo very unhandy, and ſo monſtrouſly aukward at her Needle, that I know ſhe muſt be diverting. Her Paſſion for Romances (as you muſt have obſerv'd in other Girls) took her off from every Part of uſeful Education.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: For the many Obligations I have to the Princeſſes, I ſhould (no doubt) upon all Occaſions ſhew my ſelf ready to be the But of their Ridicule.—'Tis a Duty that all great People expect from (what they call) their Dependants.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: How can you, Lady Pyrrha, miſinterpret a Civility? I know they have a Friendſhip, an Eſteem for you; and have a Pleaſure in inſtructing you.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Pyrrha, let not your captious Temper run away with your Good-manners. You cannot but be ſenſible of the King's and their Civilities, both to you and me. —How can you be ſo horridly out of Humour?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: All I mean, Madam, is; that when People are ſenſible of their own Defects, they are not the proper Objects of Ridicule.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: You are ſo very touchy, Pyrrha, that there is no enduring you.—How can you be ſo unſociable a Creature as to deny a Friend the Liberty of laughing at your little Follies and Indiſcretions? For what do you think Women keep Company with one another?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Becauſe they hate one another, deſpiſe one another, and ſeek to have the Pleaſure of ſeeing and expoſing one another's Faults and Follies.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: Now, dear Pyrrha, tell me, is Work a thing you pique yourſelf upon? Suppoſe too they ſhou'd ſmile at an Abſurdity in your Dreſs, it cou'd not be ſuch a Mortification as if (like moſt Women) you had made it the chief Buſineſs of your Life?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Don't they treat one another with equal Familiarity?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But a Reply from me (whatever was the Provocation) might be look'd upon as impertinent. I hate to be under the Reſtraint of Civility when I am ill-us'd.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Will you allow me, Madam, to make your Excuſes to the Princeſſes?—The Occaſion of your Highneſs's leaving her, I ſee, troubles her.—Perhaps I may interrupt Converſation.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: 'Tis aſtoniſhing, Child, how you can have ſo little Complaiſance. This ſullen Behaviour of yours muſt be diſagreeable. I hope, Madam, ſhe is not always in this way?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Never was any Creature more entertaining! Such Spirits, and ſo much Vivacity! The Princeſſes are really fond of her to Diſtraction.—The moſt chearful Tempers are liable to the Spleen, and 'tis an Indulgence that one Woman owes to another.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: The Spleen, Madam, is a Female Frailty that I have no Pretenſions to, nor any of its Affections.

div.head: AIR IV. Si vous vous moquez de nous.
div.l: When a Woman ſullen ſits,
And wants Breath to conquer Reaſon.
Always theſe affected Fits
Are in Seaſon:
Since 'tis in her Diſpoſition,
Make her be her own Phyſician.

sp.p: Nay, dear Madam, you ſhall not go without me.—Though I have my particular Reaſons to be out of Humour, I cannot be deficient in Good-manners.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I know they would take it mortally ill if they thought your Complaiſance had put yourſelf under the leaſt Reſtraint.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I can't forgive myſelf for my Behaviour.—You muſt excuſe me, Madam; for Abſence in Converſation is an Incivility that I am but too liable to.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You know we all rally you upon your being in Love, as that is one of its moſt infallible Symptoms.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I charge you, upon my Bleſſing;—as you expect Fame, Glory, Immortality, obey me.

div.stage: [To Achilles. Thetis kiſſes him. Exeunt Achilles and Artemona.

sp.speaker: Thetis.
sp.p: As for his Face, his Air, his Figure, I am not under the leaſt Apprehenſion; all my Concern is from the Impetuoſity of his Temper.—Yet, after all, why ſhou'd I fear a Diſcovery? for Women have the ſame Paſſions, though they employ 'em upon different Objects.

div.head: AIR V. A Minuet.
div.l: Man's ſo touchy, a Word that's injurious
Wakes his Honour; he's ſudden as Fire.
Woman kindles, and is no leſs furious
For her Trifles, or any Deſire.
Man is •• ſty,
Or ſour, or reſty,
If balk'd of Honours, or Pow'r, or Pelf.
Woman's Paſſions can no leſs moleſt ye,
And all for Reaſons ſhe keeps to her ſelf.

sp.p:
He is ſudden, he is impatient. What then? Are Women leſs ſo? Ask almoſt all Servants what they know of their Miſtreſſes. —He is wilful, teſty, and untractable. Can't
Thouſands of Husbands ſay as much of their Wives? Then as for his Obſtinacy—that can never ſhew him leſs a Woman. But he hath not that Command of his Tongue I cou'd wiſh him: He is too vehement, too ſevere in his Expreſſions. In this Particular, indeed, few Women take equal Liberties to one another's Faces, but they make ample Amends for it behind each other's Backs; ſo that, with all theſe Infirmities of Man, he may with the leaſt Conduct very well paſs for a fine-ſpirited Woman. —This Reflexion hath cur'd my Anxiety, and will make me believe him ſecure.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: 'Tis with the utmoſt Gratitude that I return your Majeſty Thanks for the Honours and hoſpitable Favours ſhewn to me and my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: You wou'd oblige me more, Madam, if your Affairs wou'd allow you to accept 'em longer.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I have preſum'd, Sir, to treſpaſs further on your Generoſity, in leaving my Daughter under your Protection.—I hope Pyrrha's Behaviour will deſerve it.

div.head: AIR VI. To you, my Dear, and to no other.

sp.l: Muſt then, alas, the fondeſt Mother
Deſert her Child?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: — Ah, why this Tear?
She'll in Theaſpe find another;
In me paternal Love and Care.

sp.p:
Had you taken her with you, my Daughters wou'd have
been miſerable beyond Expreſſion. Theirs and her Education ſhall be the ſame.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I beg you, Sir, not to regard my Gratitude like the common Obligations of Princes; for neither Time nor Intereſt can ever cancel it.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Affairs of Conſequence may require your Preſence. Importunity upon theſe Occaſions is troubleſome and unhoſpitable. —I ask no Queſtions, Madam, becauſe I chooſe not to pry into Secrets.

sp.speaker: Thet.
sp.p: I can only thank, and rely upon your Majeſty's Goodneſs. —My Duty to the Queen, Sir, calls me hence to own my Obligations, and receive her Commands.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.p: The Princeſs Caliſta hath taken her Leave; ſhe is but juſt gone out of the Room.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: That Pyrrha, Sir, was a moſt delicious Piece.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: With all her little vixen Humours, to my Taſte ſhe is infinitely agreeable.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Your parting with her, Sir, in this eaſy manner, is aſtoniſhing. One too ſo exceſſively fond of you?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Parting with her, Diphilus!

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: But no Prince alive hath ſo great a Command of his Paſſions.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Dear Diphilus, let me underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: To my Knowledge you might have had her.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Can I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: I really thought the Queen began to be a little uneaſy, and, for the Quiet of the Family (ſince ſhe is gone) I muſt own I am heartily glad of it.

div.head: AIR VII. John went ſuiting unto Joan.
div.l: How your Patience had been try'd,
Had this haughty Dame comply'd!
What's a Miſtreſs and a Wife?
Joy for Moments; Plague for Life.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I am not ſo unhappy, Diphilus.—Her Mother hath left her to my Care.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Juſt as I wiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Wou'd ſhe had taken her with her!

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: It might have been better. For beyond diſpute, Sir, both you and the Queen wou'd have been eaſier.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Why did ſhe truſt her to me?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: There cou'd be but one Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I cannot anſwer for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Twas upon that very Preſumption you was truſted.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Wou'd I could believe thee!

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Tis an apparent manifeſt Scheme, Sir, and you wou'd diſappoint both Mother and Daughter if your Majeſty did not betray your Truſt.—You love her, Sir, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: To Diſtraction, Diphilus.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: And was the betraying a Truſt ever as yet an Obſtacle to that Paſſion? What wou'd you have a Mother do more upon ſuch an Occaſion? Ladies of her Rank cannot tranſact an Affair of this kind, but with ſome Decorum.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But you can never ſuppoſe Pyrrha knows any thing of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Why not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: From me ſhe cannot; for I have never as yet made any downright Profeſſions.

sp.speaker: Diph.
Lycom.
sp.p: Be it as it will, Diphilus, I muſt have her.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Had I been acquainted with your Pleaſure ſooner, your Majeſty by this time had been tir'd of her.—How happy ſhall I make her, if I may have the Honour of your Majeſty's Commands to hint your Paſſion to her!

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Never did Eyes receive a Paſſion with ſuch Coldneſs, ſuch Indifference!

div.head: AIR VIII. Groom's Complaint.
div.l: Whene'er my Looks have ſpoke Deſire,
I ſigh'd, I gaz'd in vain;
No Glance confeſs'd her ſecret Fire;
And Eyes the Heart explain.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Though 'tis what ſhe wiſhes, what ſhe longs for, what ſhe ſighs for, Reſpect and Awe are a Reſtraint upon her Eyes as well as Tongue. I have often told you, Sir, ſhe dares not underſtand you; ſhe dares not believe herſelf ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: This Ring, Diphilus.—I muſt leave the reſt to your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: There may be a manner in giving it her, a little Hint or ſo—but the Preſent will ſpeak for itſelf; 'tis the moſt ſucceſsful Advocate of Love, and never wants an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Say every thing for me, Diphilus; for I feel I cannot ſpeak for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Cou'd I be as ſucceſsful in all my other Negotiations! Yet there may be Difficulties, for, if I miſtake not, the Lady hath ſomething of the Coquette about her; and what Self-Denial will not thoſe Creatures ſuffer to give a Lover Anxiety!

div.head: AIR IX. O'er Bogie.
div.l: Obſerve the wanton Kitten's Play,
Whene'er a Mouſe appears;
You there the true Coquette ſurvey
In all her flirting Airs:
Now pawing,
Now clawing,
Now in fond Embrace,
Till 'midſt her Freaks,
He from her breaks,
Steals off, and bilks the Chaſe.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Dear Diphilus, what do you mean? I never ſaw a Woman ſo little of that Character.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Sir; your Situation is ſuch that you can never ſee what Mankind really are. In your Preſence every one is acting a Part; no one is himſelf, and was it not for the Eyes and Tongues of your faithful Servants how little wou'd your Subjects be known to you! Though ſhe is ſo prim and
reſerv'd before you, ſhe is never at a Loſs for Airs to draw all the young flirting Lords of the Court about her.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Beauty muſt always have its Followers.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: If I miſtake not, General Ajax too (who is ſent to ſolicit your Quota for the Trojan War) hath another Solicitation more at heart.—But ſuppoſe ſhe had ten thouſand Lovers; a Woman's prevalent Paſſion is Ambition, which muſt anſwer your Ends.—The Queen is coming this way, and her Commands may detain me.—I go, Sir, to make Pyrrha the happieſt Creature upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I think the Princeſs Caliſta might as well have taken her Daughter with her.—That Girl is ſo intolerably forward, that I cannot imagine ſuch Converſation can poſſibly be of any great Advantage to your Daughter's Education.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: You ſeem of late to have taken an Averſion to the Girl. She hath Spirit and Vivacity, but not more than is becoming the Sex; and I never ſaw any thing in her Behaviour but what was extremely modeſt.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Sir, allow me to believe my own Eyes. Her Forwardneſs muſt give the Fellows ſome Encouragement, or there wou'd not be that intolerable Flutter about her.—But perhaps ſhe hath ſome Reaſons to be more upon her Guard before you.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: How can you be ſo unreaſonably cenſorious?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I can ſee her Faults, Sir. I ſee her as a Woman ſees a Woman. The Men, it ſeems, think the aukward Creature handſome.

div.head: AIR X. Dutch Skipper. Firſt Part.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: When a Woman's cenſorious,
And attacks the meritorious;
In the Scandal ſhe ſhews her own malicious Thought.
If real Guilt ſhe blames,
Then Pride her Heart inflames;
And ſhe fanſies ſhe's better for another's Fault.
Thus ſeeking to diſcloſe
The Slips of Friends and Foes,
By her Envy ſhe does herſelf alone expoſe.

sp.p: Nay, dear Child, your attacking her in this peeviſh way can be nothing but downright Antipathy.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Nay, dear Sir, your defending her in this feeling manner can be nothing but downright Partiality.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I own my ſelf partial to Diſtreſs, and I ſee her in that Circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: But there are other Reaſons that may make a Man partial.

div.head: AIR XI. Dutch Skipper. Second Part.
div.l: As you, Sir, are my Husband, no doubt you're prone
To turn each new Face
To a Wife's Diſgrace;
And for no other Cauſe but that ſhe's your own;
Nay, Sir, 'tis an evident Caſe.
'Tis ſtrange that all Husbands ſhould prove ſo blind,
That a Wife's real Merits they ne'er can find,
Tho' they ſtrike all the reſt of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: How can you be ſo ridiculous? By theſe Airs, Madam, you would have me believe you are jealous.

sp.speaker: Theſ.
sp.p: Whence had you this contemptible Opinion of me? Jealous! If I was ſo I have a Spirit above owning it. I wou'd never heighten your Pleaſure by letting you have the Satisfaction of knowing I was uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Let me beg you, my Dear, to keep your Temper.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Since I have been ſo unguarded as to own it; give me leave to tell you, Sir, that was I of a lower Rank it wou'd keep you in ſome Awe, becauſe you wou'd then know I cou'd take my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: You forget your Duty, Child.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: There is a Duty too due from a Husband.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: How can you give way to theſe Paſſions?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Becauſe you give way to yours.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But to be ſo unreaſonably jealous!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Unreaſonably! Wou'd it were ſo!

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Then muſt I bear eternal Strife,
Both Night and Day put in mind of a Wife,
By her Pouts, Spleen, and paſſionate Airs!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: D'ye think I'll bear eternal Slight,
And not complain when I'm robb'd of my Right?
Call you this, Sir, but whimſical Fears?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Can nought then ſtill this raging Storm?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: Yes. What you promis'd if you wou'd perform.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Pr'ythee teaze me no more.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: I can never give o'er,
Till I find you as fond and as kind as before.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Will you ne'er ask
A poſſible Task?

sp.p: Wou'd you have me ſo unhoſpitable as to deny her my Protection?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: 'Tis not, Sir, that I preſume to controul you in your Pleaſures.—Yet you might, methinks, have ſhew'd that Tenderneſs for me to have acted with a little more Reſerve. Women are not ſo blind as Husbands imagine.—Were there no other Circumſtances,—your Coolneſs to me, your Indifference. —How I deſpiſe my ſelf for this Confeſſion!—Pardon me, Sir, Love made me thus indiſcreet.

div.head: AIR XIII. Ye Shepherds and Nymphs.
div.l: O Love, plead my Pardon, nor plead it in vain;
'Twas you that was jealous, 'twas you was in Pain;
Yet why ſhould you ſpeak? To what Purpoſe or End?
I muſt be unhappy if Love can offend.

sp.p: Yet was ever a Deſign of this kind ſo manifeſt, ſo bare-fac'd!

div.head: AIR XIV. The Goddeſſes.
div.l: To what a Pitch is Man profuſe,
And all for oſtentatious Pride!
Ev'n Miſſes are not kept for Uſe,
But for mere Show, and nought beſide.
For might a Wife ſpeak out,
She cou'd prove beyond all doubt,
With more than enough he was ſupply'd.

sp.p: The Princeſs Caliſta hath ſhewn an uncommon Confidence in your Majeſty. The Woman, no doubt, depends upon it, that her Daughter's Charms are not to be reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Nay, dear Child, don't be ſcandalous.

div.head: AIR XV. Joan's Placket.
div.l: Reputations back'd and hew'd,
Can never be mended again;
Yet nothing ſtints the tattling Prude,
Who joys in another's Pain.
Thus while ſhe rends
Both Foes and Friends,
By both ſhe's torn in twain.
Reputations hack'd and hew'd,
Can never be mended again.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: You are in ſo particular a manner oblig'd to her, that I am not ſurpris'd at your taking her Part.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But, dear Madam, why at preſent is all this violent Fluſter?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Ask your own Heart, ask your own Conduct. Thoſe can beſt inform you.—'Twou'd have been more obliging if Pyrrha and you had kept me out of this impudent Secret.— You know, Sir, I have Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: If one Woman's Virtue depended upon another's Suſpicions, where ſhou'd we find a Woman of common Modeſty! Indeed, Child, I think you injure her; I believe her virtuous.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: When a Man hath ruin'd a Woman, he thinks himſelf oblig'd in Honour to ſtand up for her Reputation.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: If you will believe only your own unaccountable Suſpicions, and are determin'd not to hear Reaſon, I muſt leave you to your perverſe Humours.—What wou'd you have me ſay? What wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Shew your Hoſpitality (as you call it) to me, and put that Creature out of the Palace.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I have a greater Regard to yours and my own Quiet, than ever to comply with the extravagant Paſſions of a jealous Woman.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: You have taken then your Reſolutions, I find; and I am ſentenc'd to Neglect.—Did ever a Woman marry but with the Probability of having at leaſt one Man in her Power? —What a wretched Wife am I!

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Jealouſy from a Wife, even to a Man of Quality, is now look'd upon as Ill-manners, though the Affair be never ſo publick.—But without a Cauſe!—I beg you, Madam, to ſay no more upon this Subject.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Though you, Sir, may think her fit Company for you; methinks the very ſame Reaſons might tell you that ſhe is not ſo very reputable a Companion for your Daughters.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Since a paſſionate Woman will only believe herſelf, I muſt leave you, Madam, to enjoy your Obſtinacy. I know but that way of putting an end to the Diſpute.

div.head: AIR XVI. We've cheated the Parſon, &c.
div.l: Though Woman's glib Tongue, when her Paſſions are fir'd,
Eternally go, a Man's Ear can be tir'd.
Since Woman will have both her Word and her Way,
I yield to your Tongue; but my Reaſon obey.
I obey,
Nothing ſay,
Since Woman will have both her Word and her Way.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been more upon the Reſerve! But Husbands are horridly provoking; they know the Frailty of the Sex, and never fail to take the Advantage of our Paſſions to make us expoſe our ſelves by Contradiction.—Artemona.

div.head: SCENE VIII.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Is that Creature, that (what do you call her) that Princeſs gone?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Why did not ſhe take that awkward Thing, her Daughter, with her?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The Advantages ſhe mighr receive in her Education, might be an Inducement to leave her.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Might that be an Inducement?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Beſides, in her preſent Circumſtance, it might be inconvenient to take her Daughter with her.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Can't you find out any other Reaſon for leaving her?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your Courteſy, Madam; your Hoſpitality.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: No other Reaſon!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No other Reaſon?—

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd believe there was no other!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: 'Tis not for me to pry into your Majeſty's Secrets.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I hate a Girl that is ſo intolerably forward.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I never obſerv'd any thing but thoſe little Liberties that Girls of her Age will take, when they are among themſelves. —Perhaps thoſe particular Diſtinctions the Princeſſes ſhew her, may have made her too familiar.—I am not, Madam, an Advocate for her Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: A Look ſo very audacious! Now the filthy Men, who love every thing that is impudent, call that Spirit.— But there are, Artemona, ſome particular Diſtinctions from a certain Perſon, who of late hath been very particular to me, that might indeed make her too familiar.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: How precarious is the Happineſs of a Wife, when it is in the Power of every new Face to deſtroy it!—Now, dear Artemona, tell me ſincerely, don't you, from what you yourſelf have obſerved, think I have Reaſon to be uneaſy?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That I have obſerv'd!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Dear Artemona, don't frighten thyſelf.—I am not accuſing you but talking to you as a Friend.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O guard your Hours from Care,
Of Jealouſy beware;
For ſhe with fancy'd Sprites,
Herſelf torments and frights.
Thus ſhe frets, and pines, and grieves,
Raiſing Fears that ſhe believes.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I hate myſelf too for having ſo much Condeſcenſion and Humility as to be jealous. 'Tis flattering the Man that uſes one ill; and 'tis wanting the natural Pride that belongs to the Sex. What a wretched, mean, contemptible Figure is a jealous Woman! How have I expos'd myſelf!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Your Majeſty is ſafe in the Confidence repos'd in me.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: That is not the Caſe, Artemona. Lycomedes knows I am unhappy. I have own'd it, and was ſo unguarded as to accuſe him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Upon mere Suſpicion only?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.

div.head: AIR XVIII. Moll Peatly.
div.l: All Hearts are a little frail
When Temptation is rightly apply'd.
What can Shame or Fear avail
When we ſooth both Ambition and Pride?
All Women have Power in view;
Then there's Pleaſure to tempt her too.
Such a ſure Attack there's no defying,
No denying;
Since complying
Gives her another's Due.

sp.p: —I can't indeed (if you mean that) poſitively affirm that he hath yet had her.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Then it may be ſtill only Suſpicion.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I have truſted too my Daughter Deidamia with my Weakneſs; that ſhe, by her Intimacies and Friendſhip with Pyrrha, may get into her Secrets. In ſhort, I have plac'd her as my Spy about her.—That Girl (out of Good-nature, and to prevent Family-diſputes) may deceive me. She inſiſts upon it that I have nothing to fear from Pyrrha; and is ſo poſitive in this Opinion, that ſhe offers to be anſwerable for her Conduct.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why then, Madam, will you ſtill believe your own Jealouſies?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: All I ſay is, that Deidamia may deceive me; for whatever is in the Affair, 'tis impoſſible but ſhe muſt know it; I have order'd it ſo that ſhe is ſcarce ever from her; they have one and the ſame Bed-Chamber; yet ſuch is my Diſtemper, that I ſuſpect every Body, and can only believe my own Imaginations.—There muſt be ſome Reaſon that Deidamia hath not been with me this Morning.—I am impatient to ſee her.

div.head: AIR XIX. John Anderſon my Jo.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Let Jealouſy no longer
A fruitleſs Search purſue;
You make his Flame the Stronger,
And wake Reſentment too.
This ſelf-tormenting Care give o'er;
For all you can obtain
Is, what was only Doubt before,
To change for real Pain.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I Am very ſenſible, my Lord, of the particular Honours that are ſhewn me.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Honours, Madam! Lycomedes is ſtill more particular. How happy muſt that Woman be whom he reſpects!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: What do you mean, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Let this ſpeak both for him and me: The Preſent is worthy him to give, and you to receive.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I have too many Obligations already.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Tis in your Power, Madam, to return 'em all.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Thus I return 'em. And, if you dare be honeſt, tell him this Ring had been a more honourable Preſent to Theaſpe.

div.head: AIR XX. Abroad as I was walking.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.l: Such Homage to her Beauty,
What Coyneſs can reject?
Accept, as 'tis your Duty,
The Tribute with Reſpect.
What more can Beauty gain thee?
With Love I offer Power.
What Shame can ever ſtain thee,
Reſtrain thee,
Or pain thee,
When bleſt with ſuch a Dower?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Tis but an Earneſt, Madam, of future Favours.— When Lycomedes his Power is yours, I intreat your Highneſs not to forget your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I ſhall remember thee with Contempt and Abhorrence.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: I beg you, Madam, to conſider your preſent Situation. —This uncommon Diſtinction requires a ſofter Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I ſhall give no other, my Lord.—I dare ſay, Diphilus, you think yourſelf highly honour'd by your preſent Negotiation. —Is there no Office too mean for Ambition?—Was you not a Man of Quality, was you not a Favourite, the World, my Lord, wou'd call you a Pimp, a Pandar, a Bawd, for this very honourable Propoſal of yours.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: What an unmerciful Weapon is a Woman's Tongue!— I beg your Highneſs to confine yourſelf within the Bounds of common Civility, and to conſider who I am.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I do conſider it, Diphilus, and that makes thee a thouſand times the more contemptible.

div.head: AIR XXI. Butter'd Peaſe.
div.l: Shou'd the Beaſt of the nobleſt Race
Act the Brute of the loweſt Claſs;
Tell me, which do you think more baſe,
Or the Lion or the Aſs?
Boaſt not then of thy Rank or State;
That but ſhews thee the meaner Slave.
Take thy due then of Scorn and Hate,
As thou'rt but the greater Knave.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Though the Sex have the Privilege of unlimited Expreſſion, and that a Woman's Words are not to be reſented; yet a Lady, Madam, may be ill-bred. Ladies too are generally paſſionate enough without a Provocation, ſo that a Reply at preſent would be unneceſſary.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Are ſuch the Friends of Power?—How unhappy are Princes to have their Paſſions ſo very readily put in Execution, that they ſeldom know the Benefit of Reflexion! Go, and for once make your Report faithfully and without Flattery.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: This Girl is ſo exceſſively ill-bred, and ſuch an arrant Termagant, that I cou'd as ſoon fall in love with a Tigreſs. She hath a handſom Face, 'tis true, but in her Temper ſhe is a very Fury.—But Lycomedes likes her; and 'tis not for me to diſpute either his Taſte or Pleaſure.—Notwithſtanding ſhe is ſuch a Spit-fire, 'tis my Opinion the thing may ſtill do: Things of this Nature ſhou'd be always tranſacted in Perſon, for there are Women ſo ridiculouſly half-modeſt, that they are aſham'd in Words to conſent to what (when a Man comes to the Point) they will make no Difficulties to comply with.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Well, Diphilus, in what manner did ſhe receive my Preſent?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Tis my Opinion, Sir, that ſhe will accept it only from your Hands. From me ſhe abſolutely refuſes it.

div.head: AIR XXII. Come open the Door ſweet Betty.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: What, muſt I remain in Anguiſh?
And did not her Eyes conſent?
No Sigh, not a Bluſh, nor Languiſh
That promis'd a kind Event!
It muſt be all Affectation,
The Tongue hath her Heart bely'd;
That oft hath withſtood Temptation,
When ev'ry thing elſe comply'd.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: How did ſhe receive you? Did you watch her Eyes? What was her Behaviour when you firſt told her I lov'd her?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: She ſeem'd to be deſperately diſappointed that you had not told her ſo your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But when you preſs'd it to her—

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: She had all the Reſentment and Fury of the moſt complying Prude.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But did not ſhe ſoften upon Conſideration?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: She ſeem'd to take it mortally ill of me, that my meddling in the Affair had delay'd your Majeſty's Application.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: What no favourable Circumſtance!

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Nay, I was not in the leaſt ſurpris'd at her Behaviour. Love at ſecond-hand to a Lady of her warm Conſtitution! It was a Diſappointment, Sir; and ſhe cou'd not but treat it accordingly. —Whatever was my Opinion, 'twas my Duty, Sir, to obey you, but I found juſt the Reception I expected. Apply to her your ſelf, Sir; anſwer her Wiſhes, and (if I know any thing of Woman) ſhe will then anſwer yours, and behave herſelf as ſhe ought.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: But, dear Diphilus, I grow more and more impatient.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: That too by this time is her Caſe—To ſave the Appearances of Virtue, the moſt eaſy Woman expects a little gentle Compulſion, and to be allow'd the Decency of a little feeble Reſiſtance. For the Quiet of her own Conſcience a Woman may inſiſt upon acting the Part of Modeſty, and you muſt comply with her Scruples.—You will have no more trouble but what will heighten the Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Pyrrha!—This is beyond my Hopes.—Diphilus, lay your Hand upon my Breaſt. Feel how my Heart flutters.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Did Pyrrha feel theſe Aſſurances of Love ſhe wou'd not appear ſo thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Deidamia too not with her!

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: She is with the Queen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: My other Daughters, who ſeem leſs fond of her, are in the Garden; ſo all's ſafe.—Leave me, Diphilus, and let none, upon Pain of my Diſpleaſure, preſume to intrude.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Lady Pyrrha, my dear Child, why ſo thoughtful?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Thoughts may not be ſo reſpectful; they may be too familiar, too friendly, too true: And who about you preſumes to communicate 'em? Words and Forms only are for your Ear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: You know, Pyrrha, you was never receiv'd upon the Foot of Ceremony, but Friendſhip; ſo that it wou'd be more reſpectful if you was leſs ſhy and leſs reſerv'd.—'Tis your Behaviour, Pyrrha, that keeps me at a Diſtance.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: If I was wanting, Sir, either in Duty to you or my ſelf, my own Heart wou'd be the firſt to reproach me.—Your Majeſty's Generoſity is too ſolicitous upon my Account; and your Courteſy and Affability may even now detain you from Affairs of Importance.—If you have no Commands, Sir, the Princeſſes expect me in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Nay, poſitively, my dear Pyrrha, you ſhall not go.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But why, Sir?—For Heaven's Sake, what hath ſet you a trembling?—I fear, Sir, you are out of Order.—Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I did not call, Pyrrha.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Let me then, Sir, know your Commands.—

div.head: AIR XXIII. Altro Giorno in compagnia.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: If my Paſſion want explaining,
This way turn and read my Eyes;
Theſe will tell thee, without feigning,
What in Words I muſt diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Why do you fix your Eyes ſo intenſely upon me?—Speak your Pleaſure, ſpeak to me then.—Why am I ſeiz'd?— Spare me, Sir, for I have a Temper that can't bear Provocation.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I know there are a thouſand neceſſary Affectations of Modeſty, which Women, in Decency to themſelves, practiſe with common Lovers before Compliance.—But my Paſſion, Pyrrha, deſerves ſome Diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I beg you then, Sir, don't lay violent Hands upon me.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: The Preſent you refus'd from Diphilus accept from me.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Why will you perſiſt?—Nay, dear Sir, I can't anſwer for my Paſſions.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: 'Tis not Diphilus, but I give it you.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: That Diphilus, Sir, is your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: 'Tis I that offer it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Your very worſt Enemy, your Flatterer.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: You ſhou'd ſtrive, Child, to conquer theſe extravagant Paſſions.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: How I deſpiſe that Fellow! that Pimp, that Pandar!

div.head: AIR XXIV. Trip to the Landry.
div.l: How unhappy are the Great,
Thus begirt with ſervile Slaves!
Such with Praiſe your Reaſon cheat.
Flatt'rers are the meaneſt Knaves.
They, in Friendſhip's Guiſe accoſt you;
Falſe in all they ſay or do.
When theſe Wretches have ingroſs'd you,
Who's the Slave, Sir, they or you?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Is this reproachful Language, Pyrrha, befitting my Preſence?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Nay, dear Sir, don't worry me. By Jove, you'll provoke me.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Your Affectation, Pyrrha, is intolerable. There's enough of it.—Thoſe Looks of Averſion are inſupportable.— I will have no ſtruggling.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I muſt have no Violence.

div.head: AIR XXV. As I walk'd along Fleetſtreet.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: When the Fort on no Condition
Will admit the gen'rous Foe,
Parley but delays Submiſſion;
We by Storm ſhou'd lay it low.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I am in earneſt, Lady.—I will have no trifling, no coquetting; you may ſpare thoſe little Arts of Women, for my Paſſion is warm and vehement enough without 'em.—Do you know, Pyrrha, that Obedience is your Duty?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I know my Duty, Sir; and, had it not been for that Sycophant Diphilus, perhaps you had known yours.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I am not, Lady, to be aw'd and frighten'd by ſtern Looks and Frowns.—Since your obſtinate Behaviour then makes Violence neceſſary—

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: You make Self-preſervation, Sir, as neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I won't be refus'd.

div.head: AIR XXVI. The Lady's New-Year's Gift.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Why ſuch Affectation?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Why this Provocation?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Muſt I bear Reſiſtance ſtill!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Check your Inclination.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Dare you then deny me?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: You too far may try me.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: Muſt I then againſt your Will!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Force ſhall never ply me.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Never was ſuch a Termagant!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: By Jove, never was ſuch an Inſult!

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Will you?—Dare you?—Never was ſuch Strength!—

div.stage: [Achilles puſhes him from him with great Violence, and throws him down.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Deſiſt then.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Audacious Fury, know you what you have done?—

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: What Heart hath not Courage, by Force aſſail'd,
To brave the moſt deſperate Fight?
'Tis Juſtice and Virtue that hath prevail'd;
Power muſt yield to Right.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Am I ſo ignominiouſly to be got the better of!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: You are.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: By a Woman!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: You now, Sir, find you had acted a greater Part, if (in Spite of your Flatterers) you had got the better of your own Paſſions.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.p: An Attempt upon the King's Life!—The Guards! where are the Guards?

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.p: Such an open, bare-fac'd Aſſaſſination!

sp.speaker: 3 Court.
sp.p: And by a Woman too!

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.p: Where are your Wounds, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.p: Take the Dagger from her, that ſhe do no farther Miſchief.

sp.speaker: 3 Court.
sp.p: The Dagger! Where? What Dagger?

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.p: You will find it ſome where or other conceal'd; examine her, ſearch her.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Save your Zeal, Sirs, for times of real Danger. Let Lycomedes accuſe me.—He knows my Offence.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: How have I expos'd my ſelf!—Diphilus, bid theſe over-officious Friends leave me, and, as they value my Favour, that they ſay nothing of what they have ſeen.— [Diphilus talks apart with the Courtiers, who go out.] Though the Inſult from any other Perſon had been unpardonable; there are ways that you, Madam, might ſtill take to reconcile me.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Self-defence, Sir, is the Privilege of Mankind. I know your Power, but as I have offended no Law I rely upon your Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be ſafer, Madam, to rely on your own future Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Who was the Aggreſſor, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Beauty, Inclination, Love. If you will merit Favour you know the Conditions.

div.head: AIR XXVIII. Old King Cole.
div.l: No more be coy;
Give a Looſe to Joy,
And let Love for thy Pardon ſue.
A Glance cou'd all my Rage deſtroy,
And light up my Flame anew.
For though a Man can ſtand at Bay
Againſt a Woman's Will;
And keep, amid the loudeſt Fray,
His Reſolution ſtill:
Yet when conſenting Smiles accoſt,
The Man in her Arms is loſt.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: If your Reſentment wants only the Show of Juſtice; let this honourable Man here be my Accuſer; it may be neceſſary for him to trump up a horrid Conſpiracy to skreen his own infamous Practices.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: Your Majeſty hath had too much Confidence in this Woman. The Lives of Kings are ſacred, and the Matter (trivial as it ſeems) deſerves further Inquiry.—There muſt be ſome ſecret villainous Deſign in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: And are not you, Diphilus, conſcious of that ſecret villainous Deſign?

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: 'Tis an Offence, Sir, that is not to be pardon'd. Your Dignity, Sir, calls upon you (notwithſtanding your Partiality to her) to make her an Example. There muſt be Things of Conſequence that we are ſtill ignorant of; and ſhe ought to undergo the ſevereſt Examination.—My Zeal for your Service, Sir, was never as yet at a loſs for Witneſſes upon theſe Occaſions.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Don't you ſee the Queen coming this Way? Have done with this Diſcourſe, dear Diphilus, and leave me.— Wou'd I cou'd forget this ridiculous Affair! For the preſent; Pyrrha, I truſt you to return to the Ladies; though (conſidering your paſſionate Temper) I have little Reaſon to rely on your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I thought I had heard Pyrrha's Voice.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: A jealous Woman's Thoughts are her own and her Husband's eternal Plague; ſo I beg you, my Dear, ſay no more of her.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: And have I no reaſon but my own Thoughts, my Liege?

div.head: AIR XXIX. Dicky's Walk in Dr. Fauſtus.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: What give o'er!
I muſt and will complain.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: You plague us both in vain.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: You wont then hear a Wife!

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: I muſt, it ſeems, for Life.
Teaze no more.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, you know 'tis true,
That 'tis to her I owe my Due.
No Thanks to you!

sp.p: It behoves Kings, Sir, to have the ſevereſt Guard upon their Actions; for as their great ones are trumpeted by Fame, their little ones are as certainly and as widely convey'd from Ear to Ear by a Whiſper.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Theſe chimerical Jealouſies, Madam, may provoke my Patience.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Chimerical Jealouſies!—And do you really, Sir, think your ignominious Affair is ſtill a Secret?—Am I to be ignorant of a Thing that is already whiſper'd every where?

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.l: The Slips of a Husband you Wives
Will never forget:
Your Tongue for the Courſe of our Lives
Is never in debt.
'Tis now funning,
And then dunning;
Intent on our Follies alone,
'Tis ſo fully employ'd that you never can think of your own.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: My Suſpicions have, indeed, wrong'd Pyrrha.—How I reſpect and honour that Girl!—Deidamia, that honourable, that virtuous Creature Pyrrha, well deſerves both your Friendſhip and mine.—As ſoon as you have found her bring her to me, that I may acknowledge the Merits ſhe hath to me.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: After the Repulſe and Diſgrace you have very juſtly met with, you might with Reaſon cenſure me for want of Duty and Reſpect ſhou'd I upbraid you.—'Tis paſt; and if you will never again put me in mind, I chooſe to forget it.—Yet, wou'd you reward Virtue, and had you any Regard for my Quiet.—

div.head: AIR XXXI. My Dilding, my Dalding.
div.l: Ah! ſhou'd you ever find her
Complying and kinder;
Though now you have reſign'd her;
What then muſt enſue!
Your Flame, though now 'tis over,
Again will recover;
You'll prove as fond a Lover,
As I'm now of you.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I wou'd have you diſtruſt your ſelf and remove the Temptation.—I have long had it at Heart to find a Match for my Nephew Periphas, and I really think we can never meet with a more deſerving Woman.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Whatever Scheme you have for her, I ſhall not interfere with you.—I have had enough of her termagant Humours; ſhe hath not the common Softneſs of the Sex.— 'Tis my Opinion, that Periphas will not find himſelf much oblig'd to you; for the Man that marties her muſt either conquer his own Paſſions, or hers, and one of 'em (according to my Obſervation) is not to be conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
Lycom.
sp.p: Her Preſence juſt now wou'd be ſhocking.—I cou'd not ſtand the Shame and Confuſion.—I ſee her, and Deidamia with her.—Do with her as you pleaſe; you have my Conſent.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: The Character Deidamia hath given of you, and your own Behaviour, Child, have ſo charm'd me, that I think I never can ſufficiently reward your Merits.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Deidamia's Friendſhip may make her partial.—My only Merit, Madam, is Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: To convince you of the Opinion I have of you—But I muſt firſt ask you a Queſtion—Don't you think, Lady Pyrrha, that my Nephew Periphas is very agreeable?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: That Impatience of his, to ſerve as a Volunteer with the Troops of Lycomedes at the Siege of Troy, is becoming his Birth.—So much Fire, and ſo much Spirit!—I don't wonder your Majeſty is fond of him.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: But I am ſure, Pyrrha, you muſt think his Perſon agreeable.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: No Woman alive can diſpute it.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I don't know, every way, ſo deſerving a young Man; and I have that Influence upon him, and at the ſame time that Regard for him, that I would have him happy.—Don't think, Child, that I wou'd make him happy at your Expence; for, knowing him, I know you will be ſo.—Was the Princeſs Caliſta here, 'tis a Match ſhe cou'd not diſapprove of; therefore let that be no Obſtacle, for every thing, in regard to her, I take upon my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Wou'd you make me the Obſtacle to his Glory? Pardon me, Madam, I know my ſelf undeſerving.

div.head: AIR XXXII. How happy are you and I.
div.l: Firſt let him for Honour roam,
And martial Fame obtain:
Then (if he ſhou'd come Home)
Perhaps I may explain.
Since then alone the Hero's Deeds
Can make my Heart give way;
'Till Ilion falls and Hector bleeds,
I muſt my Choice delay.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Nay, Pyrrha, I won't take theſe romantick Notions of yours for an Anſwer.—Deidamia is ſo much your Friend, that, I am ſure, ſhe muſt be happy with this Alliance; ſo, while I make the Propoſal to my Nephew, I leave you two to talk over the Affair together.

div.head: SCENE X.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Was there ever a Man in ſo whimſical a Circumſtance!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Was there ever a Woman in ſo happy and ſo unhappy a one as mine!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Why did I ſubmit? why did I plight my Faith thus infamouſly to conceal my ſelf?—What is become of my Honour?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Ah Pyrrha, Pyrrha, what is become of mine!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: When ſhall I behave my ſelf as a Man!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Wou'd you had never behav'd yourſelf as one!

div.head: AIR XXXIII. Fy gar rub her o'er with Straw.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Think what Anguiſh tears my Quiet,
Since I ſuffer'd Shame for thee:
Man at large may rove and riot,
We are bound but you are free.
Are thy Vows and Oaths miſtaken?
See the Birds that wing the Sky;
Theſe their Mates have ne'er for ſaken,
'Till their Young at leaſt can fly.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Peſter'd and worried thus from every Quarter 'tis impoſſible much longer to prevent diſcovery!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Dear, dear Pyrrha, confide in me. Any other Diſcovery but to me only wou'd be inevitable Perdition to us both.— Am I treated like a common Proſtitute? Can your Gratitude (wou'd I might ſay Love!) refuſe to let me know the Man to whom I owe my Ruin?

sp.speaker: Ach.
Ach.
sp.l: Know that Importunity's in vain.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Can then nothing move thee?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Ask not ſince Denial gives me Pain.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Think how much I love thee.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: What's a Secret in a Woman's Breaſt?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Canſt thou thus upbraid me!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Let me leave thy Heart and Tongue at reſt.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Love then hath betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Deidamia, if you regard my Love, give me Quiet.—Intreaties, Fondneſs, Tears, Rage and the whole matrimonial Rhetorick of Woman to gain her Ends are all thrown away upon me; for, by the Gods, my dear Deidamia, I am inexorable.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: But, my dear Pyrrha, (for you oblige me ſtill to call you by that Name) only imagine what muſt be the Conſequence of a Month or two.—Think of my unhappy Condition.— To ſave my Shame (if you are a Man of Honour) you muſt then come to ſome Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: 'Till I deſerve theſe Suſpicions, Deidamia, methinks it wou'd be more becoming your Profeſſions of Love to ſpare 'em. —I have taken my Reſolutions; and when the time comes, you ſhall know 'em: till then be eaſy, and preſs me no farther.

div.head: AIR XXXV. My time, O ye Muſes.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: How happy my Days and how ſweet was my Reſt,
Ere Love with his Paſſions my Boſom diſtreſt!
Now I languiſh with Sorrow, I doubt and I fear:
But Love hath me all when my Pyrrha is near.
Yet why have I griev'd?—Ye vain Paſſions adieu!
I know my own Heart and I'll think thee as true;
And as you know my Heart, 'twou'd be folly to range;
For who'd be inconſtant to loſe by the Change?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: My Life, my Honour, then I implicitly intruſt with you.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Who wou'd have the trouble of putting on a Character that does not naturally belong to him! the Life of a Hypocrite muſt be one continual Scene of Anxiety. When ſhall I appear as I am, and extricate my ſelf out of this Chain of Perplexities! —I have no ſooner eſcap'd being raviſh'd but I am immediately to be made a Wife.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: But, dear Pyrrha, for my ſake, for your own, have a particular Regard to your Behaviour till your Reſolution is ripe for Execution.—You now and then take ſuch intolerable Strides, that I vow you have ſet me a bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Conſidering my continual Reſtraint, and how much the Part I act differs from my Inclinations, I am ſurpriz'd at my own Behaviour.

div.head: AIR XXXVI. I am come to your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Your Dreſs, your Converſations,
Your Airs of Joy and Pain,
All theſe are Affectations
We never can attain.
The Sex ſo often varies,
'Tis Nature more than Art:
To play their whole Vagaries
We muſt have Woman's Heart.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Your Swearing too, upon certain Occaſions, ſounds ſo very maſculine—an Oath ſtartles me.—Wou'd I cou'd cure my ſelf of theſe violent Apprehenſions!

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As for that matter, there are Ladies who, in their Paſſions, can take all the Liberties of Speech.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Then too, you very often look ſo agreeably impudent upon me, that, let me die, if I have not been mortally afraid my Siſters wou'd find you out.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Impudent! are Women ſo cenſorious that Looks cannot eſcape 'em?—May not one Woman look kindly upon another without Scandal?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p:
But ſuch Looks!—Nay, perhaps I may be particular, and it may be only my own Fears; for (notwithſtanding your
Dreſs) whenever I look upon you, I have always the Image of a Man before my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Do what we will, Love at ſome Moments will be unguarded.—But what ſhall I do about this Periphas?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: His Heart is ſo ſet upon the Siege, that I know you can have but very little Perſecution upon his Account.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd go with him!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: And cou'd you leave me thus?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: Have you only a womaniſh Fondneſs? I thought, Deidamia, you lov'd me. And you cannot truly love and eſteem, if in every Circumſtance of Life you have not a juſt Regard for my Honour.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Dear Pyrrha, don't mention it; the very Thought of it kills me. You have ſet my Heart in a moſt violent Palpitation. —Let us talk no more upon this diſagreeable Subject.— My Siſters will grow very impatient.—Shou'd we ſtay longer together I might again be importunate and ask to know you, and I had rather bear the eternal Plague of unſatisfied Curioſity, than give you a Moment's Diſquiet.—They are now expecting us in the Garden, and, conſidering my preſent Circumſtances, I wou'd not give 'em occaſion to be impertinent, for of late they have been horridly prying and inquiſitive.—Let us go to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: I envy that Periphas. His Honour, his Fame, his Glory is not ſhackled by a Woman.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Ah, why is my Heart ſo tender!
My Honour incites me to Arms:
To Love ſhall I Fame ſurrender?
By Laurels I'll merit thy Charms.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: How can I bear the Reflection

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: I balance; and Honour gives way.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Reward my Love by Affection;
I ask thee no more than I pay.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

sp.speaker: Theaſp.
sp.p: PEriphas, I have a Favour to ask of you, and poſitively I will not be refus'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Majeſty may command.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Nay, Nephew, 'tis for your own good.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To obey your Commands, Madam, muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I am not, Periphas, talking to you as a Queen, but as a Relation, a Friend.—I muſt have no Difficulties; therefore I inſiſt upon your abſolute Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am not in my own Power, Madam.—Lycomedes, you know hath acceded to the Treaty of Alliance; that to furniſh his Quota, his Troops are already embark'd, and that I have engag'd my ſelf in his Service.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Why will you raiſe Obſtacles before you know the Conditions? 'Tis a thing I have ſet my heart upon, and I tell you 'tis what in Honour you can comply with.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: My Duty, my Obligations put me entirely in your Diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: You promiſe then ſolemnly, faithfully—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I have remark'd, Periphas, that you are prodigiouſly fond of the Princeſs Caliſta's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I fond of her, Madam!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Nay, Periphas, are not you eternally at her Ear?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: How I have ſeen that formidable Hero General Ajax ſuffer upon your Account!—Of all his Rivals you are his eternal Torment.—He reddens, ſighs, and (as much as is conſiſtent with ſuch a bluſtering Soldier's Valour) languiſhes whenever you are near her.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: You may ſafely own your Paſſion, Periphas, for I know you think her agreeable.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p:
Beſides her being the faſhionable Beauty of the Court (which is ſufficient Vanity to make all the young Fellows follow her) you, of all Mankind, in Gratitude ought to like
her.—I know all of 'em envy the particular Diſtinctions ſhe ſhews you.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I am convinc'd, of her Merits; and your marrying her I know wou'd make you both happy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Let me periſh, Madam, if I ever once thought of it!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Your Happineſs you ſee hath been in my Thoughts.— I take the ſettling this Affair upon my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How cou'd you, Madam, imagine I had any Views of this kind!—What, be a Woman's Follower with Intention to marry her! Why, the very Women themſelves wou'd laugh at a Man who had ſo vulgar a Notion of Galantry, and knew ſo little of their Inclinations.—The Man never means it, and the Woman never expects it; and for the moſt part they have every other View but Marriage.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: But I am ſerious, Nephew, and inſiſt upon your Promiſe.

div.head: AIR XXXVIII. No ſooner had Jonathan leap'd from the Boat.
div.l: What are the Jeſts that on Marriage you quote?
All ignorant Batchelors cenſure by Rote;
Like Criticks you view it with Envy or Spleen.
You pry out its Faults, but the Good is o'erſeen.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my Power, Madam; 'tis not in my Inclinations.—A Soldier can have but one Inducement to marry, (and the Woman may have the ſame Reaſon too) which is, the Opportunities of Abſence.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: You know, Nephew, you have promis'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe I am already engag'd.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: That will be another Merit to her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, Madam.—In a Day or two you know I am to ſet out for the Campaign.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: A Lady of her romantic Spirit can have no Objections to following the Camp.

div.head: AIR XXXIX. Love's a Dream of mighty Pleaſure.
div.l: Soldier, think before you marry;
If your Wife the Camp attends,
You but a Convenience carry,
For (perhaps) a hundred Friends.
If at home ſhe's left in Sorrow,
Abſence is convenient too;
Neighbours now and then may borrow
What is of no Uſe to you.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I indeed fear'd Pyrrha might have ſtarted ſome Difficulties, but if you rightly conſider the Propoſal you can have none.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What is the Cauſe of the War we are now engag'd in? Does not the Fate of Menelaus ſtare me in the Face?

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I will have no more of your trifling Objections, Periphas; and as to your Part, from this time I will look upon the Affair as happily concluded.—All that now remains to be done is with Pyrrha. I have left her to Deidamia's Management; and without doubt her good Offices muſt prevail, for you can never have a better Advocate.—But ſhou'd the Girl be perverſe and obſtinate!—'Tis impoſſible. For however her Heart is already engag'd, no Woman alive can reſiſt the Ambition of ſuch an Alliance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Had I ſo little Taſte of Liberty as to be inclin'd to marry; that Girl is of ſo termagant a Spirit!—The braveſt Man muſt have the dread of an eternal Domeſtic War.—In a Tongue-combat Woman is invincible, and the Husband muſt come off with Shame and Infamy; for though he lives in perpetual Noiſe and Tumult, the poor Man is only ridiculous to his Neighbours.—How can we ever get rid of her?— Hercules conquer'd the ſeven-headed Hydra, but his Wife was a venom'd Shirt that ſtuck to him to the laſt.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: This Rencounter, Periphas, is as I wiſh'd.—The Liberties you have taken—you know what I mean—when my Honour is concern'd—an Indignity and all that!— 'Tis not to be put up; and I muſt inſiſt upon an Explanation.— There is a particular Affair, my Lord.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your accoſting me in this particular manner, Lord Ajax, requires Explanation.—For let me die, if I comprehend you!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Death, my Lord, I explain! I am not come here to be ask'd Queſtions.—'Tis ſufficient that I know the Affront, and that you know I will have Satisfaction.—So, now you are anſwer'd—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I can't ſay much to my Satisfaction, my Lord; for I can't ſo much as gueſs at your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: A Man of Honour, Periphas, is not to be trifled withal.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But a Man of Honour, Ajax, is not oblig'd in Courage to be unintelligible.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I hate talking.—The Tongue is a Woman's Weapon. Whenever I am affronted; by the Gods, this Sword is my only Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis not, Ajax, that I decline the Diſpute, or wou'd upon any Account deny you the Pleaſure of fighting; yet (if it is not too much Condeſcenſion in a Man of Honour) before I fight I wou'd willingly know the Provocation.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: What is all this idle Chat?
Words are out of Seaſon.
Whether 'tis or this or that,
The Sword ſhall do me reaſon.
Honour call'd me to the Task;
No matter for explaining:
'Tis a freſh Affront to ask
A Man of Honour's meaning.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Be it as it will, Periphas; we have gone too far already to retract.—You know, I ſuppoſe, of my Pretenſions to a certain Lady.—Now are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If you had her, my Lord, it had been much more to my Satisfaction.—I admire your Courage.

div.head: AIR XLI. Lord Frog and Lady Mouſe.
div.l: Oh, then it ſeems you want a Wife!
Shou'd I conſent,
You may repent,
And all her daily Jars and Strife
You may on me reſent.
Thus ev'ry Day and ev'ry Night,
If things at home ſhou'd not go right,
We three muſt live in conſtant Fight.
Take her at all Event.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Hell, and Furies! I am not to be rally'd out of my Reſentment.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now in my Opinion 'tis flinging away your Courage to fight without a Cauſe; though indeed the Men of uncommon Proweſs, by their loving to make the moſt of every Quarrel, ſeem to think the contrary.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: You are not ſo ſure of the Lady, Periphas, as you flatter yourſelf; for whenever I am a Rival, by Jove, 'tis not her Conſent, but my Sword, that muſt decide the Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sure never a Rival (as you will call me) had a better Reaſon for fighting than I have at preſent; for if I am kill'd, I ſhall be out of danger of having the Woman.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: You might ſpare your Jokes, Periphas, for my Courage wants no Provocation.—If I fall, Pyrrha may be yours: You will then deſerve her.—'Till then—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So he that conquers, as a Reward, I find is to be married.—Now dear Ajax, is that worth fighting for?

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Your Paſſion for that Lady, Periphas, is too publick to bear Diſpute.—Have not I ſeen you whiſper her, laugh with her? And by ſome particular Looks at the ſame time 'twas too evident that I was the Subject of your Mirth.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Looks, Ajax!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Yes Looks, my Lord; and I never did or will take an impertinent one from any Man.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Impertinent one!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: Furies! This calm Mockery is not to be born.— I won't have my Words repeated.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Such Language, Ajax, may provoke me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What means all this Ranting?

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Ceaſe your joking;
'Tis provoking.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I to my Honour will ne'er be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Will you do me right?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What means all this Ranting?

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Ceaſe your joking;
'Tis provoking.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I to my Honour will ne'er be wanting.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Talk not then but fight.
Give then by Action
Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'm not in awe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Death! will you draw, Sir?
Tittle-tattle
Is a Battle
You may ſafer try.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yet, firſt, I'd fain know why.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: By Jupiter, Periphas, 'till now I never thought you a Coward.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay then—ſince my own Honour calls upon me.— Take notice, Ajax, that I don't fight for the Woman.

sp.speaker: 1 Guard.
sp.p: Part 'em.—Beat down their Swords.

sp.speaker: 2 Guard.
sp.p: How dar'd you preſume to fight in the Royal Gardens?

sp.speaker: 1 Guard.
sp.p: Nay, in the very Preſence!—For ſee, the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard, Sirs, that a Man ſhou'd be deny'd the Satisfaction of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Lord Ajax, for this unparallel'd Preſumption we forbid you the Palace.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I ſhall take ſome other Opportunity, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: And as for you, Periphas—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Majeſty's Rigor can do no leſs than forbid me the Woman.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: The Woman, Periphas, is the only thing that can reconcile me to your Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That blundering Hero Ajax will have it that I am his Rival. The Man will be almoſt as miſerable without her, as 'tis probable he might be with her.—Oblige us both then, Madam, and let the General be miſerable in his own way.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: I cou'd not have imagin'd that obſtinate Girl cou'd have had any Scruples to the Match; but Deidamia tells me ſhe finds her as difficult as you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Since you know, Madam, that Pyrrha will have her own way; for both our ſakes, and to ſave yourſelf unneceſſary Trouble, your Majeſty had better give up this Impoſſibility.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p:
To prevent future Miſchief, my Lord, his Majeſty puts you under Arreſt, and commands you to attend him. General
Ajax is already in Cuſtody.—'Tis his Pleaſure too, that (after you have paid your Duty to him) you embark with the Troops immediately; and you are not to come aſhore again upon pain of his Majeſty's Diſpleaſure.

div.head: AIR XLIII.
div.l: In War we've nought but Death to fear,
How gracious is the Sentence!
For that is eaſier far to bear,
Than Marriage with Repentance.
Begirt with Foes, by Numbers brav'd,
I'd bleſs the happy Criſis;
The Man from greater Danger ſav'd
The leſſer ones deſpiſes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Majeſty then, you find, muſt diſpenſe with my Promiſe 'till after the Expedition.—If the General ſhou'd be ſo happy, to bring Pyrrha with him to the Camp, perhaps we may like one another better.

sp.speaker: Diph.
sp.p: The King, Madam, wants to talk to your Majeſty upon Affairs of Conſequence.—You will find him in the Royal Apartment.

sp.speaker: Theaſ
sp.p: My Daughters with Pyrrha have juſt turn'd the Walk, and are coming this way.—You may ſtay with 'em, Artemona, till I ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
'Tis horridly mortifying that theſe Trades-People will never get any thing New againſt a Birth-day. They are
all ſo abominably ſtupid, that a Woman of Fancy cannot poſſibly have the Opportunity of ſhewing her Genius.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: The Fatigue one hath of talking to thoſe Creatures for at leaſt a Month before a Birth-day is inſupportable; for you know, Siſter, when the time draws ſo very near, a Woman can think of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: After all, Siſter, though their things are deteſtable, one muſt make choice of ſomething or other. I have ſent to the Fellows to be with me this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: You are ſo eternally ſending for 'em, one wou'd imagine you was delighted with their Converſation. For thoſe hideous Stuffs they will ſhew us from Year to Year are frightful, are ſhocking. How can a Woman have ſo ill a Taſte as to expoſe herſelf in a laſt Year's Pattern!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Dear Madam, I beg your Pardon. Let me die, if I ſaw you!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Our meeting her was lucky beyond Expreſſion, for I never felt ſo uneaſy a thing as a Secret.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You know, Siſter, we had agreed to truſt her with our Suſpicions.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Yet after all when a Siſter's Reputation is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But is not the Honour of a Family of greater Conſequence?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Tho ſhe is a Woman and a Favourite, I dare ſay, if Artemona promiſes, whatever the ſuffers ſhe will inviolably keep it to herſelf.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: If I had not this Quality I had little deſerv'd Theaſpe's Friendſhip.—By all that's Sacred, Ladies, you may ſafely truſt me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, Siſter, but ſhe herſelf muſt have obſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Whatever People have obſerv'd, 'tis a thing you know, that no Creature alive can preſume to talk upon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Deal fairly and openly with us, Artemona.—Have you remark'd nothing particular of Deidamia yonder of late?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Of Deidamia!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Only look upon her, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well—what do you think of her?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Are you blind, Artemona, or dare not you believe your Eyes?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Her particular Intimacy with Pyrrha do you mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Dear Madam!—Then I find we muſt ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Now, dear Artemona, can any Woman alive imagine that Shape of hers within the compaſs of common Modeſty?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: But how can one poſſibly have thoſe Suſpicions?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She is a Woman, Madam; ſhe hath Inclinations and may have had her Opportunities that we know nothing of.

div.head: AIR XLIV. Minuet of Corelli in the Ninth Concerto.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We may reſolve to reſiſt Temptation;
And that's all we can do:
For in the Hour of Inclination
What cou'd—I or you?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Though the thing is improbable, 'tis ſo monſtrouſly evident that it cannot bear a Diſpute.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then her Boſom too is ſo prepoſterouſly impudent!— One wou'd think a Woman in her Condition was not conſcious of her own Shame.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Or imagin'd other People cou'd overlook it as well as herſelf.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then ſhe is ſo ſqueamiſh and ſo frequently out of order.—

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: That ſhe hath all the outward Marks of Female Frailty muſt be viſible to all Womankind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But how ſhe came by 'em, there, Artemona, is ſtill the Secret.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: I muſt own that, by her particular Intimacies with that forward Creature Pyrrha, I ſuſpect her to be her Confident in this Accident.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I beg you, Ladies, to turn this Diſcourſe; for Deidamia and Pyrrha are juſt coming upon us to join the Converſation.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Now I dare ſwear that careleſs Creature Pyrrha hath not once thought of her Clothes.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Nay, dear Lady Pyrrha, the thing is not ſuch a trifle, for 'tis the only Mark of Reſpect that moſt People are capable of ſhewing. And though that is not your Caſe, I know your Gratitude can never omit this publick Occaſion.

div.head: AIR XLV. Tom and Will were Shepherds twain.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Think of Dreſs in ev'ry Light;
'Tis Woman's chiefeſt Duty;
Neglecting that, our ſelves we ſlight
And undervalue Beauty.
That allures the Lover's Eye,
And graces ev'ry Action;
Beſides, when not a Creature's by,
'Tis inward Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As I am yet a Stranger, Ladies, to the Faſhions of the Country, 'tis your Fancy that muſt determine me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How can a Woman of common Senſe be ſo unſolicitous about her Dreſs!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: And truſt a Woman to chooſe for her! 'Tis a Temptation to be ſpiteful that very few of us can reſiſt; for we have not many Pleaſures that can equal that of ſeeing another Woman ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But you have not, Pyrrha, miſplac'd your Confidence.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles, Artemona, Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your Embroiderer, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
That Woman is everlaſtingly peſtering me for Employment. Now can ſhe imagine that to promote her tawdry
Trade I can be talk'd into making myſelf ridiculous by appearing eternally in her odious Embroidery?—I can't ſee her now.—But perhaps I may want her for ſome trivial thing or other.—Let her call again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The Anti-chamber, Madam, is crowded with Trades-People.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Did not I tell you that I wou'd not be troubled with thoſe impertinent Creatures?—But hold—I had forgot I ſent for 'em.—Let 'em wait.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: But if thoſe foreign Merchants who lately came into Port are among 'em—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There, Siſter, is all my Hope. I ſhall be horridly diſappointed if they don't ſhew us ſomething charming.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Shou'd any Woman alive get Sight of their things before us—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I cou'd not bear it.—To appear in what another Woman had refus'd wou'd make the Creature ſo intolerably vain!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Are thoſe Merchants I ask you among 'em?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They have been waiting, Madam, above this half Hour.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: And did not you know our Impatience?—How cou'd you be ſo ſtupid!—Let us ſee them this Inſtant.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Artemena, Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles. Ulyſſes, Diomedes, Agyrtes. [Diſguis'd as Merchants.]

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Unleſs you have any thing that is abſolutely new and very uncommon, you will give us and your ſelves, Gentlemen, but unneceſſary Trouble.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Our Experience, Madam, muſt have profited very little by the Honour of dealing with Ladies, if we cou'd imagine they cou'd poſſibly be pleas'd twice with the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Diom.
