sp.p: You might as well offer 'em the ſame Lover.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: We have learnt the good Manners, Madam, to diſtinguiſh our Cuſtomers.—To produce any thing that had ever been ſeen before wou'd be a downright Inſult upon the Genius of a Lady of Quality.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Novelty is the very Spirit of Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Let me die, if the Fellows don't talk charmingly!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Senſibly, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: 'Tis evident they muſt have had Dealings with Ladies of Condition.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: We only wait your Commands.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: We have things of all kinds, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Of all kinds!—Now that is juſt what I wanted to ſee.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Are not theſe, Siſter, moſt delightful Creatures?

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: We know a Lady can never fix unleſs we firſt cloy her Curioſity.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: And if Variety can pleaſe, we have every thing that Fancy can wiſh.

div.head: AIR XLVI. The Bob-tail Laſs.
div.l: In Dreſs and Love by like Deſires
Is Woman's Heart perplext;
The Man and the Gown ſhe one Day admires,
She wiſhes to change the next.
The more you are fickle, we're more employ'd,
And Love hath more Cuſtomers too;
For Men are as fickle, and ſoon are cloy'd,
Unleſs they have ſomething New.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: But, dear Man, conſider our Impatience.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Wou'd you command the things, Ladies, to be brought here, or wou'd you ſee 'em in your own Apartment?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How intolerably theſe Fellows love talking!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: How canſt thou, Man, ask ſuch a Queſtion!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Here—immediately.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Nay, tis not, Madam, that our Goods can be put out of Countenance by the moſt glaring Light—as for that matter—

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Nay, pry'thee, Fellow, have done.

div.stage: [Diomedes goes out and returns with Agyrtes.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: I wou'd not offer you theſe Pearls, Ladies, if the World cou'd produce ſuch another Pair.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A Pair, Fellow—Doſt thou think that Jewels pair like Men and Women becauſe they were never made to agree?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Now, Ladies, here is all that Art can ſhew you.— Open the Packet.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: This very individual Pattern, in a blue Pink, had been infinitely charming.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Don't you think it pretty, Deidamia?

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Lady Pyrrha.—Nay, dear Child, how can any Creature have ſo little Curioſity!

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Look upon it again, Madam.—Never was ſo delightful a Mixture!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: So ſoft! ſo mellow!

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: So advantageous for the Complexion!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: I can't bear it, Man; the Colour is frightful.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hate our own tame home-bred Fancy.—I own I like the Deſign—but take it away, Man.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: There muſt be ſomething pretty in every thing that is foreign.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: I am ſure, Madam, this muſt convince you to the contrary.—Never was any thing ſo deteſtable!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: For Heavens ſake, Sir, open that other Packet; and take away this hideous Trumpery.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: How coud'ſt thou make this Miſtake?—Never was ſuch an eternal Blunderer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How ridiculous is this Accident!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Pardon the Miſtake, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: A Suit of Armour!—You ſee, Philoe, they can at leaſt equip us for the Camp.

sp.speaker: Phil.
Ulyſ.
sp.p: If your Expectations, Ladies, are not now anſwer'd, let Fancy own herſelf at a ſtand. 'Tis inimitable! 'Tis irreſiſtible!

div.stage: [As the Ladies are employ'd in examining the Stuffs, Achilles is handling and poiſing the Armour, Ulyſſes obſerving him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: The Workmanſhip is curious; and ſo juſtly mounted! This very Sword ſeems fitted to my Hand.—The Shield too is ſo little cumberſome; ſo very eaſy!—Was Hector here, the Fate of Troy ſhou'd this Inſtant be decided.—How my Heart burns to meet him!

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: [Aſide to Diom. That intrepid Air! That Godlike Look! It muſt be He! His Nature, his Diſpoſition ſhews him▪ through the Diſguiſe [To Achilles.] Son of Thetis, I know thee, Greece demands thee, and now, Achilles, the Houſe of Priam ſhakes.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: But what are you, Friend, who thus preſume to know me?

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: You cannot be a Stranger, Sir, to the Name of Ulyſſes.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As I have long honour'd, I ſhall now endeavour, Sir, to emulate your Fame.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Know, Sir, Diomedes; He too is ambitious to attend you, and partake your Glory.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Come Agyrtes; with him we carry Conqueſt to the Confederates.

div.stage: [Agyrtes takes a Trumpet which lay amongſt the Armour, and ſounds.

div.head: AIR XLVII. My Dame hath a lame tame Crane.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.l: Thy Fate then, O Troy, is decreed.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: How I pant!

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: How I burn for the Fight.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Hark, Glory calls.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Now great Hector ſhall bleed.

sp.speaker: Agyr.
sp.l: Fame ſhall our Deeds requite.

div.stage: [As Achilles is going off, he turns and looks on Deidamia.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Beauty weeps.—Ah, why that Languiſh?
See ſhe calls and bids me ſtay.
How can I leave her? my Heart feels her Anguiſh.
Hence, Fame and Glory. Love wins the Day.

div.stage: Trumpet ſounds, and he takes 'em up again.

div.head: AIR My Dame hath a lame, &c.
div.p: as before, Sung in Four Parts as a Catch.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Thy Fate then, O Troy, is decreed.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: How I pant! How I burn for the Fight!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: Hark, Glory calls. Now great Hector ſhall bleed.

sp.speaker: Agyr.
sp.p: Fame ſhall our Deeds requite.

div.stage: [As they are going; Achilles ſtops with his Eyes fix'd on Deidamia.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Ladies, ſupport Deidamia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Never was any thing ſo aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Run then, Artemona, and acquaint the King and Queen with what hath happen'd.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles, Diomedes, Ulyſſes, Agyrtes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ah Siſter, Siſter, the Myſtery then of that particular Intimacy between you and Pyrrha is at laſt unravell'd.

sp.speaker: Lesb.
sp.p: Now if it had not been a Man of this prodigious Conſequence, it had been the ſame thing.—Sure never unguarded Woman was ſo unaccountably lucky!

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you leave me, Achilles?—Can you?

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Conſider your own Glory, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Why this Pain?
Love adieu,
Break thy Chain,
Fame purſue.
Ah, falſe Heart,
Can'ſt thou part?
Oaths and Vows have bound me.
Fame cries, Go;
Love ſays, No.
Why d'ye thus confound me?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Think of my Condition.—Save my Honour.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Think of the Honour of Greece.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Think of your ſolemn Oaths and Promiſes.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Nations depend upon you.—Victory, Sir, calls you hence.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you, Achilles, be perfidious?

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: Can you loſe your Glory in the Arms of a Woman?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.p: Can you ſacrifice the Fame of your faithful Deidamia?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: O, what a Conflict's in my Breaſt!

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.l: What, ſtill in ſuſpence? bid Fame adieu.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: See me with Shame oppreſt:
I curſe, yet I love thee too.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.l: Let not her Sighs unman your Heart.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Can you then go, and Faith reſign?

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Shou'd I!—How can I part?

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: Your Honour is link'd with mine.

div.head: SCENE The Laſt.
div.stage: Philoe, Lesbia, Deidamia, Achilles, Ulyſſes, Artemona, Diomedes, Agyrtes, Lycomedes, Theaſpe, Diphilus, Periphas, Ajax.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: Hence, Diphilus; and preſume no more to come into my Preſence. 'Twas your paltry Flattery that made me ridiculous.—Such a Genius can never be at a loſs for Employment, for I have found you qualified for the very meaneſt Offices.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: My Daughter, Sir, I hope, hath put Confidence in a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: My Word, Madam, is as ſacred as the moſt religious Ceremony.—Yet (though we are already ſolemnly betroth'd to each other) 'tis my Requeſt, Madam, that before I leave the Court the Prieſt may confirm the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
Lycom.
sp.p: You muſt own, Madam, that 'twas your own Jealouſies that were the Occaſion of Deidamia's Diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: How can you have the Aſſurance to name it? Does it not put you in mind of your own?—Let her Marriage to Achilles make us forget every thing paſt.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: As you was ſo furiouſly in Love, Lord Ajax, I hope I ſhall ſtill retain your Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: No joking I beg you, young Man.—But pr'ythee, how came you here? and in a Woman's Dreſs too!—Your ſetting out, Stripling, did not ſeem to promiſe much.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: The Adventure wou'd be too long to tell you.—I ſhall reſerve the Story for the Camp.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The Prieſt, Sir, is ready.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: The Ceremony waits you.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: It ſhall be my Study, Lycomedes, to deſerve this Alliance.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: May you be happy!

sp.speaker: Theaſ.
sp.p: Let the Prieſt then join your Hands.

div.stage: [Achilles, Deidamia, Lycomedes, Theaſpe, Lesbia, Philoe, Artemona, retire to the back part of the Stage. The Prieſt performs the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Our Duel, Ajax, had made a much better Figure if there had been a Woman in the Caſe.—But you know, like Men of violent Honour, we were ſo very valiant that we did not know what we were fighting for.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: If you are too free with your Wit, Periphas, perhaps we may know what we quarrel about.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: What teſty, Ajax! Petticoats have led many a Man into an Error. How lucky was the Diſcovery! for had you found a real complying Woman you had irretrievably been married.—The Preſence of Achilles ſhall now animate the War.

div.head: AIR LI. The Man that is drunk, &c.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was ever a Lover ſo happily freed!

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Try me no more; and mention it never.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.l: Suppoſe you had found her a Woman indeed.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Muſt I be teaz'd and worried for ever!

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: By Conqueſt in Battle we finiſh the Strife;

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But Marriage had kept you in Quarrels for Life.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.l: Muſt you be fleering?
Truce with your jeering.
Know that you Wits oft' paid for your ſneering.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If you had been deceiv'd by a Woman—'tis what we are all liable to.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.p: But Ajax is a Man of warm Imagination.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: After this Day let me hear no more of this ridiculous Affair.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay for that matter any Man might have been deceiv'd; for Love, you know, is blind.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: With my Sword I can anſwer any Man.—I tell you, I hate joking.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
sp.p: I have the common Cauſe ſo much at Heart that I wou'd not, Son, detain you from the Siege.

div.head: AIR LII. There liv'd long ago in a Country Place.

sp.speaker: Deid.
sp.l: How ſhort was my Calm! in a Moment 'tis paſt;
Freſh Sorrows ariſe, and my Day is o'ercaſt.
But ſince 'tis decreed.—Let me ſtifle this Tear.
Be bold, yet be cautious; my Life is thy Care;
On thine it depends; 'tis for thee that I fear.

sp.speaker: Lycom.
Ajax.
sp.p: But hearkee, young Fellow,—This is the old Soldier's Play; for we ſeldom leave Quarters but the Landlord's Daughter is the better for us.—Hah!

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.p: We may for a while put on a feign'd Character, but Nature is ſo often unguarded that it will ſhew itſelf.—'Tis to the Armour we owe Achilles.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.l: Nature breaks forth at the Moment unguarded;

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Through all Diſguiſe ſhe her ſelf muſt betray.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.l: Heav'n with Succeſs hath our Labours rewarded.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Let's with Achilles over Genius obey.

sp.speaker: Ulyſ.
sp.l: Thus when the Cat had once all Woman's Graces;
Courtſhip, Marriage won her Embraces:
Forth lept a Mouſe; ſhe, forgetting Enjoyment,
Quits her fond Spouſe for her former Employment.

div.head: CHORUS.
Minuet of Corelli.
div.l: Nature breaks forth at the Moment unguarded;
Through all Diſguiſe ſhe herſelf muſt betray.
Heav'n with Succeſs hath our Labours rewarded;
Let's with Achilles our Genius obey.

div.p: February 28, 1733. Juſt Publiſh'd, A SELECT COLLECTION of MOLIERE's CoMEDIES, French and Engliſh, in EIGHT POCKET VOLUMES, neatly Printed on a Fine Paper, with a curious Frontiſpiece to each Comedy. To which is prefix'd a curious PRINT of the AUTHOR, and his LIFE in French and Engliſh; Extracted from Monſieur Bayle, Rapin, &c.

N. B. That it may be ſeen how much the Engliſh Stage has been indebted to Moliere, we have, in this Catalogue, plac'd ſuch of Our Comedies as have been founded upon His over-againſt the Originals, from whence they were taken.

list.item: A DEDICATION of the Whole WORK to HER MAJESTY.
The LIFE of the AUTHOR.
A General PREFACE to the Whole WORK.

Dedicated to His Royal Highneſs the Duke.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable Philip Earl of Cheſterfield.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable the Lady Harriot Campbell.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable Sir William Yonge, Knight of the Bath.
Dedicated to Mr. Wyndham of Clower-Wall, in Glouceſterſhire.
8 George Dandin, ou le Mari Confondu.
George Dandin, or the Husband Defeated.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable the Lady ___…
Dedicated to His Grace the Duke of Montagu.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable the Lady Mary Wortley Montagu.
Dedicated to the Right Honourable George Dodington, Eſq
Dedicated to the Right Honourable the Lady Harvey.
12 Tender Husband, Steele. 12 Le Sicilien, ou L'Amour Pointre.
The Sicilian, or Love makes a Painter.
Dedicated to Her Grace the Dutcheſs of Richmond.
Dedicated to His Grace the Duke of Argyle.
13 Impertinents, Shadwell. 13 Les Faſcheux. The Impertinents.

div.p: ⁂ Just Publiſh'd, The TRAVELS and ADVENTURES of the Sieur JACQUES MASSE: Being a very entertaining Account of his Arrival in an unknown Country in Terra Auſtralis, after having ſuffer'd two Shipwrecks: Of the ſtrange Manners and Cuſtoms of the People: Of his curious Converſations with the Prieſts, Judges, and with the KING himſelf, on the Subjects of Religion, Trade, and almoſt all the Arts and Sciences: Of his Paſſage from the Southern Countries to Goa, where he was impriſon'd in the Inquiſition: Of his being taken by Pirates in his Voyage from thence to Lisbon; and of his Ranſom from Slavery, and Arrival at London: Beſides many other moſt diverting Incidents, which are very agreeably interſpers'd in the Narrative.

Just Publiſh'd, The BOARDING SCHOOL; or, The SHAM CAPTAIN. An Opera. As it is perform'd at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majeſty's Servants: Written by Mr. COFFEE, Author of the Beggar's Wedding, and The Devil to Pay. With the Muſick prefixt to each Song.
Alſo juſt Publiſh'd the laſt New Play, call'd, CAELIA, or, The Perjur'd LOVER, as it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majeſty's Servants.
N. B. This Play is founded on a True Tragical Story in Common Life, and the Incidents very Natural and Moving.
And the Second Edition of The MOCK DOCTOR: Or, The DUMB LADY Cur'd, a Comedy done from Moliere, with additional SONGS and Alterations.

*†* Feb. 28, 1732. In a few Days will be Publiſh'd, The MISER. A Comedy, taken from Plautus and Moliere. By HENRY FIELDING, Eſq. As it is now Acting at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by His Majeſty's Servants.
div.trailer: Printed for John Watts at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn Fields.
